courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: The geological origin, occurrence, and hazards of volcanoes and earthquakes. Plate tectonic theory, efforts at forecasting these events, and effects on human populations will be discussed. Core: Biological & Physical Sciences.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Composition and structure of the earth, the internal and external forces acting upon it, and the surface features resulting. Laboratory studies of common rocks and minerals, geologic and topographic maps, and aerial photographs. Field trips required. Three lecture hours and three laboratory hours per week. Students who have successfully completed the honors version of this course (GEOL 122) will not receive additional credit for this course. Core: Biological & Physical Sciences. Lab/Class fee will be assessed.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Advanced study of physical geology with a focus on Earth’s materials, processes, and history. Honors College course. Students who have successfully completed the non-honors version of this course will not receive additional credit for this course.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: The history and development of the continents and ocean basins and the evolution of life on earth will be discussed based upon information obtained from the sedimentary rock record. Field trips required. Three lecture hours and three laboratory hours per week.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.courseTitle: SUSTAINABILITY AND THE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES
courses.description: Explores the use and sustainability of natural resources in light of environmental challenges, such as climate change and resource depletion.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Study of the relationship between human activities and Earth’s geologic processes, including land use, pollution, and the effects of natural hazards.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Introduction to the study of fossils, their occurrence, and the history of life on Earth. Includes methods of fossil identification and their use in understanding past environments.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Study of Earth’s structural features, including faulting, folding, and the processes that shape the Earth’s crust.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Study of minerals, including their identification, properties, and significance to geologic processes.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.courseTitle: PETROLOGY OF IGNEOUS AND METAMORPHIC ROCKS
courses.description: Study of the origin, classification, and composition of igneous and metamorphic rocks.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Introduction to the study of the oceans, including physical, chemical, and biological oceanography.
prerequisites: 7 units of BIOL, CHEM, GEOL, or PHYS courses

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Study of geochemical methods used in environmental science, including analysis of soil, water, and air samples.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Study of groundwater, including its movement, storage, and contamination in the Earth's subsurface.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Study of plate tectonics and Earth’s lithospheric processes, including earthquakes, volcanic activity, and mountain building.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Study of sediments and sedimentary rocks, their formation, and their role in reconstructing Earth’s history.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: The study of special topics in the Geosciences. Special Topics will be determined by their need for study and relevance to existing courses. May be repeated with a different topic for a maximum of 6 units.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Developing a research question, designing research projects, writing a proposal, scientific report writing, and oral presentation. As a final project, students develop a research proposal.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Independent research in geology, supervised by a faculty member. Requires a final research report.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Directed readings in geology, focused on specific topics of interest in the field.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Introduction to geologic mapping and field techniques, including topographic and geologic maps, geologic cross sections, rock identification, and geological data collection.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Investigation of field problems and phenomena. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Individual project in any branch of geology. Students will develop and execute a research project under the supervision of a faculty member.

courses.subject: GEOL
courses.description: Completion of an honors thesis in geology, based on individual research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.
